These are the gruesome facial injuries suffered by an aspiring model after she tried to pet a stranger's dog . 
Shannon Clark was left with gaping wounds to her mouth and chin after the animal turned on her without warning . 
Shannon documented the slow recovery of the wounds she suffered six months ago and it is likely she will be left with some permanent scarring, the Daily Record reported . 
The dog lover from Helensburgh, Argyll and Bute , decided to make the pictures public to warn others. 
She was left with blood gushing down her face and jagged cuts piercing right through her mouth and chin after the attack near her home in June last year. Read More Gruesome photos show sickening wounds suffered by six-year-old boy savaged by dog which mauled him to the bone The dog bit Shannon without warning leaving her with gaping wounds (Photo: Shannon Clark/Deadline News) 
Shannon, who now has her own beloved pooch, Tilly, feared at the time her injuries would never heal and that her career in modelling would be over. 
Writing an inspirational New Year message to her friends, she said: "So in July 2016 I got bitten by a random dog and thought that it would never heal properly and would stop all my chances of modelling. 
"This didn't happen and It's been healing really well and I've got lots of paid shoots and built my confidence straight back up. 
"I know that 2017 will be an amazing year for me and although I wouldn't change what happened in 2016 cause it made me grow as a person and realise that my opinion of myself is the only one that matters. 
"I wish everyone the best start to their 2017 and I know lots of people are happy to get 2016 over with. 
"I'm just so thankful that I've recovered and that it wasn't more serious." 
Shannon explained: "I don't know the dog or the owner as I never saw the owner and the dog ran away. 
"But I want to raise awareness about being too overly friendly with random dogs." 
In October last year, startling figures revealed the number of Scottish people needing hospital treatment for dog attacks had soared by 50 per cent in the past ten years. 
More than 55,093 people attended A&E for bites from dogs between 2006 and 2015. Read More 'Pit bull' called Scarface attacks three family members after owner tries to dress him in Christmas jumper But with some carefully applied make-up the scar is barely visible (Photo: Shannon Clark/Deadline News) 
According Freedom of Information figures from all of Scotland's health boards, 6,061 victims visited medical staff in 2015 - up from 4,053 in the corresponding period ten years ago. 
And out of the total amount of victims that were injured, 5,899 were children under nine. 
According to website PetGuide, members of the public should always take careful steps when approaching and petting dogs. 
They state: "While some dogs may be socialized enough to respond in a friendly manner, not all dogs will be okay with a stranger approaching and laying hands on them. 
"Do not assume that it will be okay just because the dog "looks" friendly. When a dog is frightened or feels threatened he can become defensive or aggressive. This can happen in an instant and you might not have time to retreat. 
"Do not put your face close to the dog and definitely do not try to hug or kiss him. Dogs do not understand this type of affection and a strange dog might perceive it as a threat." Like us on Facebook
